doc:
GtkHeaderBar is similar to a horizontal . It allows children to be placed at the start or the end. In addition, it allows a title and subtitle to be displayed. The title will be centered with respect to the width of the box, even if the children at either side take up different amounts of space. The height of the titlebar will be set to provide sufficient space for the subtitle, even if none is currently set. If a subtitle is not needed, the space reservation can be turned off with .

GtkHeaderBar can add typical window frame controls, such as minimize, maximize and close buttons, or the window icon.

methods.doc: Retrieves the custom title widget of the header. See .
methods.name: get_custom_title

methods.doc: Retrieves whether the header bar reserves space for a subtitle, regardless if one is currently set or not.
methods.name: get_has_subtitle

methods.doc: Returns whether this header bar shows the standard window decorations.
methods.name: get_show_close_button

methods.doc: Retrieves the subtitle of the header. See .
methods.name: get_subtitle

methods.doc: Retrieves the title of the header. See .
methods.name: get_title

methods.doc: Adds child to bar, packed with reference to the end of the bar.
methods.name: pack_end

methods.doc: Adds child to bar, packed with reference to the start of the bar.
methods.name: pack_start

methods.doc:
Sets a custom title for the .

The title should help a user identify the current view. This supersedes any title set by or . To achieve the same style as the builtin title and subtitle, use the “title” and “subtitle” style classes.

You should set the custom title to null, for the header title label to be visible again.
methods.name: set_custom_title

methods.doc:
Sets the decoration layout for this header bar, overriding the setting.

There can be valid reasons for overriding the setting, such as a header bar design that does not allow for buttons to take room on the right, or only offers room for a single close button. Split header bars are another example for overriding the setting.

The format of the string is button names, separated by commas. A colon separates the buttons that should appear on the left from those on the right. Recognized button names are minimize, maximize, close, icon (the window icon) and menu (a menu button for the fallback app menu).

For example, “menu:minimize,maximize,close” specifies a menu on the left, and minimize, maximize and close buttons on the right.
methods.name: set_decoration_layout

methods.doc: Sets whether the header bar should reserve space for a subtitle, even if none is currently set.
methods.name: set_has_subtitle

methods.doc: Sets whether this header bar shows the standard window decorations, including close, maximize, and minimize.
methods.name: set_show_close_button

methods.doc:
Sets the subtitle of the . The title should give a user an additional detail to help him identify the current view.

Note that GtkHeaderBar by default reserves room for the subtitle, even if none is currently set. If this is not desired, set the property to false.
methods.name: set_subtitle

methods.doc: Sets the title of the . The title should help a user identify the current view. A good title should not include the application name.
methods.name: set_title

name: HeaderBar

properties.doc:
The decoration layout for buttons. If this property is not set, the setting is used.

See for information about the format of this string.
properties.name: decoration-layout

properties.doc: If true, reserve space for a subtitle, even if none is currently set.
properties.name: has-subtitle

properties.doc:
Whether to show window decorations.

Which buttons are actually shown and where is determined by the property, and by the state of the window (e.g. a close button will not be shown if the window can't be closed).
properties.name: show-close-button
